items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
This is an opportunity for members of the public to address the Board concerning issues not listed on the agenda.
	 
The Board welcomes this opportunity to hear from the public and has established a policy for the public's participation in board meetings, which is outlined in BP 2345. This policy states that:
	 
No member of the public may speak without being recognized by the President of the Board.
Each speaker will be allowed a maximum of three minutes per topic. Thirty minutes shall be the maximum time allotment for public speakers on any one subject regardless of the number of speakers at any one Board meeting. At the discretion of a majority of the Board, these time limits may be extended.
The Board recognizes the need to encourage public participation but also recognizes the need to preserve order and the proper functioning of the meeting. Citizens addressing the Board at meetings shall therefore conduct themselves at all times in a manner appropriate to the setting.

items.item_details: The District employs non-bargaining unit employees in various categories to support programs and services.  These categories are: short-term assignments with limitations as defined in the CSEA/District collective bargaining agreement; substitutes to fill positions for employees on leave of absence or in vacant positions; professional experts with specialized knowledge or expertise not generally required of, or found within, the employee classifications established by the Governing Board; and athletic support staff for athletic activities.

items.item_details:
Education Code 81655 stipulates that no contract is an enforceable obligation of the District until it has been approved by the Board of Trustees. Board Policy 6100 established the authority of certain administrators to approve contracts under the bid limit prior to formal Board approval. All contracts, purchase orders and contract revisions exceeding the current bid limit of $87,800 shall have prior Board approval as a separate board item.
This consent item presents for Board approval: all purchase orders for this period, which includes purchase orders for administratively approved contracts exceeding $1,000, as well as additional contracts, although not executed by way of purchase order, are deemed appropriate to be added by the Purchasing Department.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees ratify the contracts, purchase orders and contract revisions for the period of March 10, 2016 through April 9, 2016 as noted in the attached documents.
items.item_text: Ratification of Contracts, Purchase Orders and Contract Revisions
items.item_text_raw: 6. Ratification of Contracts, Purchase Orders and Contract Revisions

items.item_details:
Per California Public Contract Code Section 20652, "the governing board of any community college district without advertising for bids, and when the board has determined it to be in the best interest of the district, may authorize by contract, lease, requisition or purchase order ... (to) purchase materials, supplies, equipment ... and other personal property for the district in the manner in which the public corporation or agency is authorized by law to make the lease or purchase." The contract must be based on the same prices and upon the same terms and conditions of a negotiated contract between the supplier and another public corporation agency.
	 
Furthermore, per Public Contract Code 20653.5 (also know as Assembly Bill 653 - Postsecondary Education: Community College Contracting Practices), effective January 1, 2016, "Nothing in this code shall preclude the governing board of a community college district from purchasing materials, equipment, supplies, or services under the same terms and conditions as are specified in a contract lawfully awarded by the University of California or the California State University."
	 
Therefore, when considering the best interest for the District, it is recommended that the Board of Trustees award a piggybackable contract between the California State University, Office of the Chancellor and SHI without the need to further advertise for bids on an already competitively bid contract. 
	 
Attached are Request For Proposal Number 3705 for Software Reseller Services issued by the California State University, Office of the Chancellor, a Notice of Intent to Award, and Foundation for California Community Colleges Administrative Services Agreement (CB-194-16) with Exhibit B.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees authorized the District to 'piggyback' on a contract with Software Hardware Integration (SHI) International Corporation.

items.item_details:
The accreditation standards require that colleges periodically assess and reaffirm their institutional Mission Statements.  Toward this end, the College Advisory Council (CAC) has been assessing and reviewing SJCC's Mission Statement since the Fall 2015 semester.  It has been vetted several ways, seeking input and feedback from the campus community: through The Roar e-newsletter; via campus-wide email announcement; and as a discussion item in the CAC and Academic Senate.  The Academic Senate sent their approved Mission Statement with a recommendation of acceptance to the CAC on April 5, 2016.  At its April 15 meeting, the CAC approved the Mission Statement and sent a recommendation to President Breland for Adoption.
	 
The Mission Statement defines the institution's broad educational purposes, it's intended population, and its commitment to achieving student learning.
	 
SJCC Mission Statement
	 
The Mission of San Jose City College is to serve our students and the community by offering high quality, relevant, and innovative instruction for basic skills, career pathways, university transfer, and life-long learning. We strive to accomplish this by awarding certificates and associate degrees to eligible students taught in a multicultural environment where student achievement, successful learning and social justice are highly valued, supported, and continually assessed.
	 
The Vision of San Jose College is to be an educational institution of excellence through:
	 
The guiding principles of opportunity, equity, and open, equitable access for student success and achievement.
	 
An exceptional learning environment that challenges and empowers students through teaching excellence, robust student support programs, innovation, and state-of-the-art technologies that prepare students with the knowledge, relevant transferable skills, creativity, ethics and values to succeed and thrive in a dynamic healthy global environment.
	 
A culture of inquiry and evidence that is characterized by the commitment of faculty, staff and students to be accountable for learning excellence through the assessment of measurable and meaningful learning outcomes that lead to improved learning, and to inform data-driven decisions that foster adaptability in programs and services.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the San Jose City College Mission Statement.
items.item_text: Mission Statement - San Jose City College
items.item_text_raw: 9. Mission Statement - San Jose City College

items.item_details:
Statway, the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching's Pathway Initiative, is a year-long introductory college-level statistics course that replaces the traditional sequence of elementary algebra > intermediate algebra > college-level math requirement. Statway has been approved for transfer by the UC  and CSU systems, and is specifically intended for students on the Liberal Arts Pathway who don’t need the same breadth and depth of algebra as students on alternate math pathways: namely, the Statistics Pathway (e.g. Business, Economics) or STEM Pathway (e.g. Science, Technology, Engineering, Math). Statway incorporates unique pedagogical approaches that promote collaborative learning and addresses socio-emotional factors affecting student success. At SJCC, only 15% of students successfully complete the traditional sequence, which is also the national average.  49% of Statway students successfully complete in 1 year. Statway has been demonstrated to increase success for first-generation, low-income, Hispanic, and African-American students.  Statway requires a 1-time licensing fee of $25K, which has been included in this year’s Student Equity budget per VP Montemayor. The envisioned schedule for adoption at SJCC is as follows: 
Math Department vote to approve Statway adoption (Done - Feb 2016)
Statway faculty identified (Done - April 2016)
Statway license paid: May 2016
SJCC Statway Courses (MATH 064/065) submitted for approval by UCs/CSUs: 2016/17 academic year
SJCC Statway faculty attend national training: July 2017 (paid by student equity or division funds)
SJCC Statway kick-off: Fall 2017
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Memorandum of Agreement with Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching to implement Statway math courses.
items.item_text: Approval of Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching Statway Math Pathway Agreement
items.item_text_raw: 10. Approval of Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching Statway Math Pathway Agreement

items.item_details:
In FY 2011-2012 in an effort to reduce receivables, the District enhanced its focus in this area by contracting with an external collection agency as part of a multi-pronged solution.  The District's current contract for external collection agency services with Account Control Technology (ACT) is expiring.  Accordingly the District issued an RFP in February 2016 to seek proposals from qualified organizations to perform receivables recovery assistance.  The District received four responses and rated the responses based upon the following criteria: capacity to perform (30%); pricing (25%); recovery rate (25%); reference checks (15%); and small business (5%).  The Evaluation Committee invited three of the four responders to provide a presentation to the committee inclusive of sample correspondence that would be submitted to debtors on behalf of the District.  The Evaluation Committee is unanimously recommending Continental Services Group, Inc. to provide external collection agency services to the District.  In exchange, the contractor will receive 18.5% of revenues collected, which is a reduction from the 25% under the current contract.  The contractor is also barred from referring any debt to any credit reporting agency as the District's goal is to reduce receivables without negatively impacting a debtor's credit score.
	 
For reference is the internal process leading up to any student account being referred to the contractor and the proposed contract.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees award a three-year contract with two optional one-year extensions to Continental Services Group, Inc. to assist the District in reducing receivables.
items.item_text: External Collection Agency Contract
items.item_text_raw: 11. External Collection Agency Contract

items.item_details:
Proposition 39 is the California Clean Energy Jobs Act which allocates revenue to the Clean Energy Job Creation Fund for five fiscal years, beginning with fiscal year 2013-2014.  Eligible Districts can request funding by submitting an energy expenditure plan application to the California Energy Commission.  The Energy Commission approves plans and works with the California Department of Education which distributes the funds after plans have been approved.
	 
Salas O’Brien was awarded a Master Agreement by the Board of Trustees on May 25, 2012.
	 
The scope of this PAA #EVC-10 is to provide complete design, construction administration and closeout services for the Energy Efficiency-Clean Energy Year 3 Projects for San Jose Evergreen Community College District.  This will include Building Management Systems (BMS) controls upgrade at both campuses, replacing the boiler and adding a variable frequency drive (VFD) to heating hot water pumps at EVC Physical Education building, replacing VFDs to cooling towers and heating hot water pumps at SJCC Central Plant, Business Building, Career Center, Library Research Center and providing BMS controls for the SJCC Science Building fume hoods.  This will also include lighting controls upgrade, connection and programming as part of the BMS at EVC and SJCC for all exterior and parking lot lighting.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Project Assignment Amendment (PAA) No. EVC - 10 in the amount of $35,000.00 to Salas O’Brien for Design and Construction Phase Services, Energy Efficiency-Clean Energy Project #25103 at San Jose City College (SJCC) and Evergreen Valley College (EVC).

On June 25, 2014 the Board of Trustees agreed to enter into contract with Eagle Enterprises for Division of the State Architect (DSA) Inspection Services for the South Campus Development Project #32107 at Evergreen Valley College. 
	 
Independent Contractor Agreement (ICA) Revision No. 001 includes additional DSA testing and inspection services to July 31, 2016 for the South Campus Project.  Eagle Enterprises is required to provide these services through completion of the project.  The proposal has been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.

Previous Approved Revisions      $         00.00
This Revision No. 001                  $    3,500.00
Total Contract and Changes         $453,500.00

items.item_details:
On August 26, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved an Agreement to Blach Construction Company in the amount of $41,639,729 to provide construction services for the South Campus Development Project #32107 at Evergreen Valley College.
Change Order No. 016 includes Work that is the result of costs from:  the addition of security key FOBs for the access control system, the addition of the media converters for the Talk-A-Fone System and additional tree drainage for site landscaping.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
Original Contract Amount                                             $41,639,729.00
Previous Approved Changes                                        $     431,929.00
Change Order No. 016                                                 $          8,294.00
Total Contract and Changes                                         $42,079,952.00
	 
The net change to Blach Construction Company’s contract as a result of all changes issued is $440,223.00 which equates to 1.05% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change.
	 
The Project Completion Date remains unchanged at March 10, 2016.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 016 in the amount of $8,294.00 to Blach Construction Company for the South Campus Development Project #32107 at Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_text_raw: 3. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College South Campus Development Project #32107 – Blach Construction Company Change Order No. 016

items.item_details:
On March 11, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved a contract to Kitchell CEM Inc. in the amount of $4,914,192.00 to provide construction services for the Career Technical Education Buildings 100 and 200, Project # 31107-2 at the SJCC. 
	 
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions; District requested or design changes that require an adjustment to the contract, scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Change Order No. 010 is to extend the duration of Kitchell’s contract aligning it with the date of completion as denoted on the Notice of Completion.  
	 
Soon after the original completion date of the Career Technical Education Buildings 100 and 200, Project it was discovered that there were a myriad of deficiencies and incomplete work. Kitchell CEM Inc. was notified of this and throughout the year, and into the following summer, Kitchell worked to remedy these deficiencies. Due to the fact that their original contractual completion date was September 2nd 2014 and their actual completion date ended up being March 7th 2016 a zero dollar change order capturing a time extension is necessary in order to close out the project.
	 
Original Contract Amount                $4,914,192.00
Previous Approved Changes           $   797,261.00
Change Order No. 010                    $              0.00
Total Contract and Changes            $5,711,453.00
	 
The net change to Kitchell CEM’s contract as a result of all changes issued will be 552 Calendar Days and $797,261.00 which equates to 16% of the base contract. This change is not monetary therefore the project budget will not be affected.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 010 extending the Kitchell CEM Inc., construction contract timeframe to the date of completion as denoted on the Notice of Completion for the Career Technical Education Buildings 100 and 200 Project at SJCC.

items.item_text_raw: 4. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: San Jose City College (SJCC) Career Technical Education Project #31107-2 – Buildings 100 & 200 Change Order No. 010

items.item_details:
The scope of this Agreement provides a comprehensive renovation to the interior finishes of 23 classrooms and a conference room in the General Education Building. The scope of the first phase covered by this action includes replacement of ceiling tile, light fixture lenses, window coverings, painting, data and electrical outlets, new paint, and floor cleaning and sealing.  
	 
The project was posted on the District’s purchasing website and advertised in local papers on April 1, 2016 and April 8, 2016. It was published at local builders’ exchanges and plan rooms.  In addition, invitations to bid were sent to many contractors including small minority and woman-owned firms.  On April 21, 2016 construction bids were received as follows:
	 
Company Name                                                           Base Bid ($)                            Total Contract Value ($)
ICC General Contractors Inc.                                      $424,380                                $424,380
CRW Industries, Inc.                                                    $502,299                                $502,299
CAM Painting, Inc.                                                       $588,000                                $588,000
Piana Construction and Painting Inc.                          $614,000                                 $614,000
	 
ICC General Contractors Inc. is the apparent lowest bidder and it is recommended the award go to this contractor for $424,380.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees award an Agreement in the amount of $424,380 to ICC General Contractors Inc. for the GE Building Interior Finishes Project #31335 at SJCC.

items.item_details:
On April 29, 2016, President Obama issued a Presidential Proclamation proclaiming May 2016 as Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month.  Following is an excerpt of this Proclamation: 
	 
"Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders (AAPIs) are the fastest growing racial group in our country, growing over 4 times as rapidly as the population of the United States.  As one of the most culturally and linguistically diverse groups in America, the AAPI community reminds us that though we all have distinct backgrounds and origins, we are bound in common purpose by our shared hopes and dreams for ourselves and our children.  Our Nation's story would be incomplete without the voices of countless Asian Americans, Native Hawaiians, and Pacific Islanders who have called the land we all love home.  This month, we honor the irreplaceable roles they have played in our past, and we recommit to ensuring opportunities exist for generations of AAPIs to come.
	 
"...Peoples of diverse backgrounds and circumstances have long come to our country with the faith that they could build a better life in America, and spanning generations, the story of AAPIs in the United States embodies this promise.  During Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month, let us celebrate the many contributions our AAPI brothers and sisters have made to the American mosaic, and let us renew our commitment to creating more opportunities for AAPI youth as they grow up and embrace the hard work of active citizenship, adding their unique voices and experiences to our Nation's narrative.
	 
"NOW, THEREFORE, I, BARACK OBAMA, President of the United States of America, by virtue of the authority vested in me by the Constitution and the laws of the United States, do hereby proclaim May 2016 as Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month.  I call upon all Americans to visit www.WhiteHouse.gov/AAPI to learn more about our efforts on behalf of Asian Americans, Native Hawaiians, and Pacific Islanders, and to observe this month with appropriate programs and activities."
	 
In support of this proclamation and in celebration of the achievements of Asian American and Pacific Islander faculty, administrators, staff and students, Evergreen Valley College and San Jose City College organized events in which Asian American and Pacific Islander culture is celebrated. Thanks to planning groups and participants for these celebration and educational events.  
	 
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approves Resolution No. 051016-2 in support of May 2016 as Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Resolution No. 051016-2 in support of May 2016 as Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month
items.item_text: Resolution No. 051016- in support of May 016 as Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month
items.item_text_raw: 2. Resolution No. 051016-2 in support of May 2016 as Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month

items.item_details:
The Education Code designates the third full week in May as Classified School Employee Week.  Section 88270 states “All community colleges shall annually observe that week in recognition of classified school employees and the contributions they make to the educational community.”
	 
The attached resolution recognizes the important contributions made by classified employees of the San José∙Evergreen Community College District and extends the celebration to the full month of May 2016.  
	 
The District Office will hold a Service Award Ceremony and each college will organize at least one event.

items.item_details:
Pursuant to Educational Code Section 5322 and Elections Code Section 13307 the Governing Board members must determine the content of the attached resolution for the Order of Election, Specifications of the Election Order and Consolidation Request to send to the Santa Clara County Registrar of Voters.
		 
In addition, on January 10, 2006, the Board approved the following policy regarding filing fees for the office of District Trustee:
		 
BP 2140 Partial Reimbursement for Candidate Filing Fees
		 
The district shall reimburse the Registrar of Voters for 3/4s of the filing fees and the candidate would pay 1/4th of the filing fees.

items.item_details: At the last Board Legislative Committee Open Session of February 10, 2016; a list of 12 bills were introduced. This small number was indicative of the "early period" within the legislative session and its bill deadline of February 19, 2016.  On February 19 and just before, the bulk of bills were introduced to the Legislature. A review of these newly entered bills and subsequent research and meetings with staffers and bill authors produced a list of 42 bills that fell within the parameters of the Board Legislative Committee's priority of student success or other relevant areas to support or monitor.  These 42 bills are submitted for discussion and approval.  With an approval, the Board Legislative Committee staff can move forward with letters of support, testimony and other related activities relative to each position recommended.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees vote for approval of the Board Committee on Legislation's list of 42 bills for support or monitoring during the 2016 legislative session.

items.item_details:
To comply with Governmental Accounting Standards Board (GASB) Statements 43 and 45, the San Jose Evergreen Community College District developed and implemented a Substantive Plan focused on the delivery and funding of health and welfare benefits for eligible retirees and their spouses.
	 
Taxable Other Post Employment Benefits (OPEB) bonds were issued on May 14, 2009, in the amount of $46,775,000 to fund this liability and the funds were deposited into an OPEB Irrevocable Trust.  Issuing the bonds ensured that the District complied with GASB Statements 43 and 45; allowed the District to determine how the benefit costs and long-term liability would be funded over time; and provided the District with initial savings to the Unrestricted General Fund.  It is noted that the District incorporated capitalized interest to satisfy the debt service for the first two years; thereby, avoiding any OPEB-related debt service payments from District funds in the first two years.
	 
On March 13, 2012, the Board of Trustees adopted Resolution 031312-2 authorizing the re-marketing of the bonds to further reduce the exposure to the Unrestricted General Fund and to lock in a fixed rate for 15 years.  It is projected that in FY 2015-2016 the Unrestricted General Fund will contribute $1,884,759 toward the $2,478,541 debt-service obligation with the difference of $593,782 funded by the revenues associated with the long-term land lease with Imwalle Properties for the shopping center located on the corner of Yerba Buena and San Felipe.  The total debt-service obligation of $2,478,541 remains less than the projected cost of benefits totaling $3,685,962.
	 
The actuarial study by Nyhart dated June 30, 2015, determined that the long-term liability associated with these benefit commitments was $40,512,573 with net assets of $48,049,215, which means that the liability was over-funded as of June 30, 2015, by $7,536,642 or a funded ratio of 119%.
	 
The Retirement Board of Authority (RBOA) oversees and implements the OPEB Trust, which has a targeted net investment rate of return of 7.88% and possesses net assets of $44,599,593.60 as of March 31, 2016.
	 
Attached for reference is the performance letter dated April 20, 2016, from Benefit Trust; the Consolidated Asset Report as of March 31, 2016; and the Actuarial Report as of June 30, 2015.

items.item_text_raw: 1. Retirement Board of Authority Annual Report

items.item_details:
This information item will provide a status update on the Measure G-2004 & Measure G-2010 bond programs and highlight several of the active projects as well as provide a review of Gilbane's performance through year five (FY2015/16) and information relating to the renewal of Gilbane's agreement for year six (FY2016/17). 
	 
The District successfully passed Measure G-2010 on November 2, 2010.  On January 25, 2011 a facilities and bonds study session served as an opportunity to share a framework for success for Measure G-2010.  Included in this framework was the recommendation that the District utilize a program and construction management firm to provide program and construction management services to the colleges and District to support implementation of various construction and deferred maintenance projects. In keeping with the District's desire to promote accountability, efficiency and cost effectiveness, the District went through a formal Request for Qualifications process to seek the services of a Program and Construction Management firm to provide system-wide coordination and oversight of all capital improvement work performed under the Measure G-2010 bond program.  Gilbane Building Company was selected through this process.
	 
Since the initial one-year contract with Gilbane, awarded by the Board on May 10, 2011, policies and procedures for operating under the Bond have been implemented, overall program and detailed project scheduling has been established and maintained, accounting and purchasing procedures have been put in place and numerous projects are either in design, construction, or have been completed and turned over to the colleges for occupancy.  Each contract was for time and materials only at a not-to-exceed amount, with the fifth year (FY2015/16) value of $5,297,131.  The agreement has the option to renew annually through 2018.  The proposed contract amount for the sixth year (FY2016/17) is valued at $6,087,934.
	 
As for the Measure G-2004 bond program, the FY2015/16 contract is $1,306,030 and the proposed FY2016/17 contract is $358,339.
	 
The Board is being asked to review this information on May 10, 2016 and then take action on a year six (FY2016/17) contract renewal for the Measure G-2010 bond program and a contract for FY2016/17 for the Measure G-2004 bond program at the June 14, 2016 Board of Trustees meeting.

items.item_details:
Per its adopted governing principles, the Board of Trustees will evaluate its performance at the end of each meeting.
	 
The Board will consider two items in discussing its evaluation:
	 
1.To ascertain the effectiveness of the meeting in attaining the advancement of the Board's Global Ends Policy.
	 
2.To ascertain the degree to which Trustees adhered to the Board adopted Governance Principle: Trustees Code of Conduct.
